metadata.synopsis: After the party has slain a group of undead scholars, the judge of death--Jergal--climbs out of his sarcophagus to greet them. He has been locked inside for years by the god Helm to atone for his part in raising the Dead Three, wicked gods who are now plotting to conquer the realms. Jergal is emotionless and excessively formal, both resigned to his fate and that of others. He is here to assist the party because that is his divine oath, not out of any true desire to act. Players can attempt to goad or attack him, but to minimal effect, as he is functionally immortal. His only goal was to see their faces, so he can find them at camp later to offer further assistance.

59.speaker: Withers
59.text: Neither thy outburst nor thy apology is relevant.

14.speaker: Withers
14.text: See what thou hast seen. Know what thou knowest.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: Can you not be harmed? What magic is this?

3.speaker: Withers
3.text: Fate has not declared mine injury. Therefore, it shall not occur.

8.context: CinematicNodeContext: Jergal climbing out of his tomb and standing up before the player

56.speaker: Withers
56.text: So he has spoken, and so thou standest before me. Right as always.

69.speaker: Withers
69.text: What a curious way to awaken.

9.speaker: Withers
9.text: Now I have a question for thee: what is the worth of a single mortal's life?

67.speaker: Withers
67.text: Ah, but thou lack a voice to speak. No matter. I have seen enough.

62.speaker: Withers
62.text: We will see each other again at the proper time and place. Farewell.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: Quite the question. What's the reason for it?

1.speaker: Player
1.text: 'So he has spoken'? What 'he' are you talking about?

33.speaker: Withers
33.text: An arbiter of certain matters. But that is not important now.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: Little spooked by the crawling out of the tomb bit. What are you?

36.speaker: Withers
36.text: I am not the same as those thou hast slain, if that is what thou askest.

35.speaker: Player
35.text: A peaceful undead. Interesting. Why aren't you attacking me?

57.speaker: Withers
57.text: So I ask again: what is the worth of a single mortal life?

43.speaker: Player
43.text: Mortals live to die. To be slaughtered.

5.speaker: Withers
5.text: We have met and I know thy face.

70.speaker: Withers
70.text: We will see each other again at the proper time and place. Farewell.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: Mine seems worth little, as my blood calls me to harm others.

77.speaker: Player
77.text: No one life is worth more than any other. We are all equal.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: That depends on a person's deeds.

24.speaker: Withers
24.text: I am sure thou believest as such.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: Life's only value is as currency. Doesn't matter to me otherwise.

78.speaker: Withers
78.text: To some, it is the only currency.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: Each life is of infinite value and merits sacrificing everything for.

31.speaker: Withers
31.text: And thus balance is achieved. If all are at war, none can win.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: The only life that matters is mine.

34.speaker: Withers
34.text: At this particular junction, perhaps that is not so far from the truth.

44.speaker: Withers
44.text: I am curious by what standards thou shalt judge.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: A life is only valuable in service to Vlaakith.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Life only has value where Lolth decrees it.

25.speaker: Player
25.text: Some mortals live much longer than others. I can't compare them.

68.speaker: Withers
68.text: It is mortality just the same.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: In my experience, that depends on what the mortal looks like.

74.speaker: Withers
74.text: A life and how it is lived are different equations.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: A life is worth only as much as the legends remember it.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: Mortal lives are not 'single'. They are part of a greater whole - a path to enlightenment.

72.speaker: Withers
72.text: Few strive for such balance. Fewer still achieve it.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: That depends on the virtue of the life that is lived.

73.speaker: Withers
73.text: That is true, but matters not.

65.speaker: Withers
65.text: Dull your weapons as you wish.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: What manner of undead are you to ask such a question?

7.speaker: Player
7.text: You feel familiar. Do I know you?

66.speaker: Withers
66.text: Yes, but I imagine it is not the way thee believe.

41.speaker: Withers
41.text: Thou walk with death, child of Myrkul. That is enough for an understanding between us.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: You feel familiar. Do I know you?
